issues.text: whether Special Rules framed by the Governor of Andhra Pradesh under proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution to the extent the same permitted appointment by transfer to a higher category on the basis of seniority-cum-efficiency were violative of para 5(2) of the Presidential Order issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution of India, 1950

anchor.surface_text: In V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors.  2001  10 SCC 401, a three-Judge Bench was examining whether Special Rules framed by the Governor of Andhra Pradesh under proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution to the extent the same permitted appointment by transfer to a higher category on the basis of seniority-cum-efficiency were violative of para 5 2  of the Presidential Order issued under Article 371-D

issues.text: whether the term 'transfer' in para 5(2) of the Presidential Order includes promotion

anchor.surface_text: This Court further held that while para 5 2  authorised the State Government to make provisions for transfer in certain specified circumstances, yet the term transfer could not be enlarged in its amplitude so as to include promotional aspects. This Court observed We find that para 5 2  of the Presidential Order speaks of transfer and not of promotion.

arguments.claim: Predominant legal opinion limits doctrine of prospective overruling to Supreme Court only; neither Tribunal nor High Court can invoke

anchor.surface_text: There was some debate at the Bar whether the High Court could have invoked the doctrine of prospective overruling even if the State Administrative Tribunal was incompetent to do so. It was contended by the counsel appearing for the respondents that the predominant legal opinion emerging from the pronouncements of this Court limited the application of the doctrine of prospective overruling only by the Supreme Court.

arguments.court_reasoning: Acknowledges Golak Nath but shows evolution via precedents

arguments.claim: Supreme Court can invoke doctrine of prospective overruling even if High Court cannot; justified by law in flux, non-impleadment, equity

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Jayant Bhushan, learned senior counsel appearing on behalf of the respondent, on the other hand, argued and, in our opinion, rightly so that it was unnecessary for this Court to go into the question whether the doctrine of prospective overruling was available even to the High Court. He urged that there could be no manner of doubt that even if the High Court was not competent to invoke the doctrine, nothing prevented this Court from doing so having regard to the fact that those promoted under the impugned rules had held their respective positions for a considerable length of time making reversion to their parent zone cadre not only administratively difficult but unreasonably harsh and unfair.

arguments.claim: Doctrine of prospective overruling applicable here to save pre-7.11.2001 promotions; law in flux, non-parties affected, equity, Art 142 power

anchor.surface_text: We have heard learned counsel for the parties at length. The doctrine of prospective overruling has its origin in American jurisprudence. It was first invoked in this country in C. Golak Nath Ors. v. State of Punjab Anr. AIR 1967 SC 1643, with this Court proceeding rather cautiously in applying the doctrine, was conscious of the fact that the doctrine had its origin in another country and had been invoked in different circumstances.

arguments.claim: Petitioners did not take calculated risk; promotions ordered by State when law valid, no risk element

anchor.surface_text: While doing so we must at the threshold point out that the respondents are not correct in suggesting as though the petitioners had taken any deliberate or calculated risk by opting for promotion outside their cadres. The respondents have while making that assertion ignored the fact that promotions were ordered by the State and not snatched by the petitioners.

arguments.claim: V. Jagannadha Rao case concerns different G.O.Ms., no bar to applying prospective overruling here

anchor.surface_text: Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of norms comprising GoMs No.14 and 22 referred to earlier.

holdings.text: The impugned G.O.M. No.14 dated 26th November, 1994 as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996 are constitutionally impermissible to the extent they provide for appointment by transfer of Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers from Head Offices and Factories/Boilers Departments to the post of Assistant Labour Officer, being in violation of the Presidential Order under Article 371-D.

anchor.surface_text: finally declared that provisions like the one made by the rules in the instant case are constitutionally impermissible being in violation of the Presidential Order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying the binding precedent in V. Jagannadha Rao which held similar provisions violative of paras 3 and 5 of Presidential Order as Presidential Order prevails over inconsistent rules under Art 309.

holdings.text: The doctrine of prospective overruling is invoked by this Court to limit the effect of the declaration of invalidity of the impugned G.O.Ms. prospectively from 7th November, 2001, saving all appointments, promotions and actions taken thereunder prior to that date with no reversion or disturbance.

anchor.surface_text: Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra

holdings.reasoning_summary: Law in flux till VJR; promotions made when rules valid; affected parties not impleaded; long passage of time (10 years); equity and administrative difficulty; power under Art 142 to mould relief for complete justice; precedents like Golak Nath, Kailash Chand Sharma.

holdings.text: The judgment in V. Jagannadha Rao does not preclude this Court from invoking the doctrine of prospective overruling as it concerned different G.O.Ms. and did not address the question.

anchor.surface_text: Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of norms

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction in facts and G.O.Ms.; VJR did not consider prospective overruling.

holdings.text: Promoted employees did not take any calculated risk as promotions were ordered by the State Government when the rules were considered valid, without any pending legal controversy.

anchor.surface_text: While doing so we must at the threshold point out that the respondents are not correct in suggesting as though the petitioners had taken any deliberate or calculated risk by opting for promotion outside their cadres.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: Reversion of the petitioners to their parent cadre is therefore bound to have a cascading effect, prejudicing even those who are number parties before us. The fact that the petitioners were number arrayed as parties before the Tribunal or before the High Court also brings the fact situation of the present case closer to that in Kailash Chands case supra . The law in the present case was, as in Kailash Chands case supra , in a state of flux. Such being the position, we see numberreason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case.

outcome.relief_summary: Doctrine of prospective overruling invoked to protect promotions made prior to 7th November, 2001 from being disturbed
